newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, Electronic Arts to offer games on ICTV network.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, Electronic Arts to offer games on ICTV network.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. and Electronic Arts Inc., two of the biggest publishers of video game software, agreed to offer some of their games through ICTV Inc.'s Internet-access network, ICTV said.

ICTV offers a so-called "virtual PC," a small settop box with a keyboard that connects to a customer's television set. ICTV supplies access to the Internet and video games through cable-TV wire connected to the settop box.
The local cable television company charges a monthly fee for access to the ICTV system.
Getting the backing of Microsoft and Electronic Arts is a "vote of confidence" for the ICTV business model, the company said.

"In a sense, ICTV ultimately will produce a no-risk way for people to get into PCs, or add a second one for the family," said Wesley Hoffman, president of ICTV, a closely held company based in Los Gatos, Calif.
ICTV will supply Microsoft and Electronic Arts games in a field test being held in Santa Barbara, Calif.
The games include Microsoft's Deadly Tide, Golf and Return of Arcade. The Electronic Arts titles include Need for Speed and FIFA Soccer '97.
ICTV competes with a handful of TV-based Internet-access providers, including WebTV Networks Inc. In April, Microsoft agreed to pay about $425 million to buy WebTV.
